channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Apple’s A.I. Chief, John Giannandrea, Is Retiring
item.description: John Giannandrea, hired from Google, is leaving after the release of a new Siri was postponed. Apple has fallen behind rivals in efforts to develop A.I. products.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: SAN FRANCISCO, CA - SEPTEMBER 19: Google's Senior VP of Engineering John Giannandrea speaks onstage during TechCrunch Disrupt SF 2017 at Pier 48 on September 19, 2017 in San Francisco, California. (Photo by Steve Jennings/Getty Images for TechCrunch)
item.media:description: Steve Jennings/Getty Images for TechCrunch

item.title: Pace, Di Donna and David Schrader Join Forces to Form New Art Gallery
item.description: Pace, Di Donna and David Schrader of Sotheby’s are collaborating on an Upper East Side space that will focus on secondary market sales.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: via Pace Gallery, Photo by Thomas Loof; George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: The exterior of Pace Gallery, New York (left), and the Di Donna Gallery (right). They will merge into a new location on the Upper East Side, and David Schrader will join the leaders of those galleries in a new venture.

item.title: TSA Imposes $45 Fee for Travelers Without REAL ID Starting February 2026
item.description: As of February, passengers without the government-approved identity card will be required to pay for alternative screening at U.S. airports.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: A T.S.A. worker checks a traveler’s ID at the international airport in Oakland, Calif.

item.title: To Avoid Pharma Tariffs, U.K. Agrees to Trump’s Demand to Pay More for Drugs
item.description: President Trump has complained that wealthy countries like Britain pay too little for drugs, leading America to bear much of the burden of the costs of medicines.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Jonathan Nackstrand/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A lab run by the drugmaker AstraZeneca. President Trump has complained that wealthy European countries pay too little for medicines.

item.title: For ‘No Tax on Tips,’ the I.R.S. Gets Intimate
item.description: The Trump administration wants to exclude earnings from “pornographic activity” from a new tax break for tips. Will the I.R.S. know it when it sees it?
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Antonio Sortino

item.title: College Students Choosing A.I. Majors Over Computer Science
item.description: At M.I.T., a new program called “artificial intelligence and decision-making” is now the second-most-popular undergraduate major.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Rune Fisker

item.title: A Surprise When Your Package Arrives: You Have to Pay the Tariff
item.description: The end of a tariff exemption on goods worth $800 or less has left some U.S. shoppers with an extra shipping bill that must be paid before delivery.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kim Batten purchased her coat from a Dutch retailer. After it shipped, she learned she’d need to pay over $250 in customs duties.

item.title: I Made an Offensive Joke. But So Did Everyone Else! Why Did I Get Fired?
item.description: Plus, should you endure a stultifying work life to enable a happy personal life?
item.dc:creator: Max Read
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: Markets Defy the White House
item.description: Volatility has returned to stocks and crypto trading, despite assurances from a top administration official, as investors brace for more data on consumers.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Brendan McDermid/Reuters
item.media:description: Markets are slipping despite signs of resilient consumer spending.

item.title: OpenAI Takes Stake in Thrive Holdings, a Buyer of Services Firms
item.description: The move by the parent company of ChatGPT is meant to help imbue Thrive Holdings’ accounting and I.T. services companies with artificial intelligence tools.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sam Altman of OpenAI. The company is betting that taking a stake in Thrive Holdings, which is incubating services companies, will showcase how businesses should adopt artificial intelligence.

item.title: Hong Kong Contractors Used Unsafe Netting at Fire Site, Officials Say
item.description: Investigators say contractors wrapped the buildings in substandard scaffolding netting and then sought to hide it from inspectors. The toll from the fire rose to 151.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Joy Dong and Selam Gebrekidan
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Green netting and bamboo scaffolding are visible on buildings at Wang Fuk Court, the Hong Kong apartment complex engulfed by fire last week.

item.title: People Are Ordering Smaller Pizzas and Fewer Toppings. What Does That Tell Us?
item.description: Sales are softening at big chains and independent shops aren’t selling as many extras. Competition, diet trends and consumer anxiety may all be playing a part.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerry Carollo, the owner of Prima Pizza Kitchen in Somerville, N.J., said that customers used to regularly add drinks and sides to their pizza orders. But that is no longer the case.

item.title: Young Workers Learn to Embrace the Office
item.description: Remote work means less training and opportunity for advancement, especially for younger workers, research suggests. Some are getting the message.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Madeline Cass for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aerlice LeBlanc enjoyed remote work for a software company, but wondered if it was limiting her career. “I got the sense there were conversations happening at work, about work things, that I wasn’t part of because I wasn’t physically there,” Aerlice LeBlanc said.

item.title: For Some U.K. Businesses, Trump’s Tariffs Are a Price Worth Paying
item.description: Some British business owners are determined to keep their access to American consumers, but they are facing trade-offs.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson

item.title: Get Ready, America: Here Come China’s Food and Drink Chains
item.description: China’s fast-food and beverage brands have an opportunity to expand in the United States and escape cutthroat competition at home.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi, Joy Dong and Ava Pellor
item.media:description: Staff members preparing drinks at Heytea in Times Square. The chain has its roots in Jiangmen, in southern China.

item.title: ‘Zootopia 2’ Goes Wild at the Worldwide Box Office
item.description: The Disney sequel took in $156 million in North America over its first five days. Strong turnout in China pushed the film’s global opening total to $556 million.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes

item.title: Two Retail Chiefs Take Stock of a Make-or-Break Holiday Shopping Season
item.description: The leaders of Nordstrom and Selfridges are dealing with tariffs, a tough economy and a fight for relevance.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Victor Llorente for The New York Times; Charlotte Hadden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pete Nordstrom, left, outside the Nordstrom flagship store in Manhattan and André Maeder inside the London flagship Selfridges department store.

item.title: Silicon Valley’s Man in the White House Is Benefiting Himself and His Friends
item.description: David Sacks, the Trump administration’s A.I. and crypto czar, has helped formulate policies that aid his Silicon Valley friends and many of his own tech investments.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang, Tripp Mickle, Ryan Mac, David Yaffe-Bellany and Theodore Schleifer
item.media:credit: Mark Harris

item.title: Colleen Jones, Curling Champion and Broadcaster, Dies at 65
item.description: She won two world titles and six Canadian national championships, and was also a television anchor, reporter and commentator.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.media:credit: Andy Clark AC/Reuters
item.media:description: Colleen Jones during a curling match in 2002. She was inducted into Canada’s Sports Hall of Fame in 2016.

item.title: U.S. Black Friday Sales Defy Tariffs and Economic Woes
item.description: Data on spending this week shows that consumers are shopping big for the holidays despite inflation and economic worries.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers outside the Macy’s flagship store in Midtown Manhattan on Black Friday afternoon.

item.title: Meet the Millionaire Masters of Early Decision at Colleges
item.description: The enrollment chiefs at Tulane and the University of Chicago attracted many early applicants. Now both of them earn a lot of money.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber
item.media:credit: Robert Neubecker

item.title: Call My Agent, the Basketball Version
item.description: There have never been more basketball stars from France. Two best friends saw it coming decades ago and are reaping the benefits.
item.dc:creator: Tania Ganguli
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bouna Ndiaye, left, and Jérémy Medjana have led their agency, Comsport, to become the premier agency for French basketball players. They represent the N.B.A. superstar Victor Wembanyama.

item.title: N.Y. Law Could Set Stage for A.I. Regulation’s Next ‘Big Battleground’
item.description: The new law seeks to prevent retailers from ripping off consumers by using artificial intelligence and their personal data to charge them higher prices.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York law, which represents a significant step in the nationwide push to regulate how businesses use their customers’ data, drew criticism and litigation from the start.

item.title: Deadly Hong Kong Fire Is a Test of Beijing’s Rule in the City
item.description: After Beijing reshaped the political order in Hong Kong in its image, the fire has become a test of how well that new system can govern in a crisis.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue and retrieval workers at the Wang Fuk Court towers in Hong Kong, on Friday.

item.title: F.D.A. Seeks More Oversight of Vaccine Trials and Approvals
item.description: The agency’s top vaccine regulator proposed broad changes, claiming that a new review linked 10 children’s deaths to the Covid vaccine. But public health experts questioned the findings, wanting to examine the data.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Vinay Prasad, the F.D.A.’s top vaccine official, suggested in a memo that the deaths were related to vaccine-related myocarditis but did not offer data to support his conclusions.

item.title: Airbus Orders Software Update for A320 Jets
item.description: The European airplane maker said a recent incident had shown that “intense solar radiation may corrupt data critical to the functioning of flight controls.”
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Armando Franca/Associated Press
item.media:description: The emergency fix comes during one of the busiest travel periods of the year in the United States.

item.title: Late Rally Pushes Stocks Back Near Record High
item.description: A midmonth stumble, driven by worries about the frenzy around artificial intelligence, was reversed as investors inched back into stocks this week.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: A Fascinating Tale, Unearthed at a Sidewalk Sale
item.description: After a crowded stoop sale on a Brooklyn block caught one reporter’s eye, he traced the items to Georgia — and an elusive figure known as Miss Paula.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of articles of clothing sat abandoned in a closed vintage store in Georgia. Some of those items were sold at a sidewalk sale earlier this year in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

item.title: Shoppers Head Into the Holidays With Spending Plans Intact
item.description: Prices are higher, and the job market is weakening, but many people plan to spend heartily this season.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of New York

item.title: How the Snowbird Ski Resort in Utah Readies the Slopes
item.description: Before skiers and riders hit the slopes, a team works from dusk to dawn to prepare the mountain. We went behind the scenes to see how they do it.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli and Ruth Fremson

item.title: Carney Lifts Climate Laws for New Alberta Pipeline
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney reached a tentative deal with the province as part of his program to curb the country’s economic dependence on the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Todd Korol/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney with Premier Danielle Smith of Alberta on Thursday in Calgary.

item.title: Robert A.M. Stern, Architect Who Reinvented Prewar Splendor, Dies at 86
item.description: He designed museums, schools and libraries before winning international acclaim late in life for 15 Central Park West in Manhattan, hailed as a rebirth of the luxury apartment building.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Richard Perry/The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert A.M. Stern in 2007. Glowing reviews drove a stampede of celebrities to 15 CPW — the building he described as “my breakthrough” — overshadowing the competition from sleek glass towers that had been the rage in Manhattan early in the new millennium.

item.title: Black Friday Deals Can Put People in Debt. Here’s How to Manage It.
item.description: The convenience of one-click purchases and “buy now, pay later” loans is making it easier for people to shop — and shop and shop — during the holidays.
item.dc:creator: Juli Fraga and Connie Chang
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kristen Conti, 60, sought help after spending more than $1,000 on Labubu dolls and Christmas decorations. She has over $50,000 in credit card debt.

item.title: Sean Duffy Longs for the ‘Golden Days’ of Air Travel. What Was That Like?
item.description: Back in the ’50s and ’60s, passengers (well-dressed, of course, and with perfect manners) could count on hot meals on china, plenty of legroom, the occasional piano bar, even wool blankets. Those days are gone.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Pictorial Parade/Archive Photos, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Fewer people flew in the 1960s, which allowed airlines to use the extra space for lounges where people drank and socialized.

item.title: Gen X-ers Have Money to Spend. Why Are Retailers Ignoring Them?
item.description: Three in four Americans ages 45 to 60 say they expect to overspend for the holidays. They’re “sort of like the glue within the consumer spectrum.”
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone
item.media:credit: Janne Iivonen

item.title: During the Holidays, Retailers Want Social Media Attention
item.description: Experts say that keeping holiday posts festive but not focused on sales is an effective strategy.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Felder
item.category: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Paris department store Samaritaine Paris Pont-Neuf has a giant Advent calendar with numbers positioned along its grand staircase. Patrons can learn of the surprise behind each date in the store or by watching Samaritaine’s Instagram Stories.

item.title: Campbell’s Says Executive Accused of Offensive Remarks Has Left the Company
item.description: The comments came to light after an audiotape was released, tied to a lawsuit filed by a former employee.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: J. David Ake/Associated Press
item.media:description: Campbell’s said it learned about an audiotape reportedly featuring the voice of a company executive when a lawsuit was filed last week.

item.title: U.K. Budget Plan Calms Markets and Labour Faithful. Will It Appeal to Voters?
item.description: The plan presented by the chancellor of the Exchequer, Rachel Reeves, called for spending increases and higher taxes on the wealthy and the middle class.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Justin Tallis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rachel Reeves, Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, carries a red box symbolizing the presentation of a new government budget on Wednesday in London.

item.title: As Prices Pinch, Bessent Looks for Ways to Mollify Wary Consumers
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has offered a variety of creative justifications for President Trump’s import duties.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent speaking to the press at the White House in November. Mr. Bessent has stifled his skepticism about tariffs since being tapped by Mr. Trump for the Treasury role.

item.title: Kevin Hassett Reportedly Becomes Front-Runner for Fed Chair
item.description: Kevin Hassett, a top White House economic adviser, is said to become the front-runner to lead the Federal Reserve, raising questions about its independence.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kevin Hassett, a close economic adviser to President Trump, has reportedly emerged as a front-runner to be the next Fed chair.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: Firefighters tried to douse the blaze at an apartment complex in the city’s northern Tai Po district, which killed at least four people.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Joy Dong, Keith Bradsher, Anushka Patil and Tina Zhou

item.title: Retail Earnings Show Shoppers’ Resilience, but Some Stores Struggle
item.description: Companies said they managed tariff pressures in the latest quarter as consumers focused on discounts and high quality.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Black Friday shoppers at a mall in Albany, N.Y., last year. The holiday shopping season is a critical period for retailers.

item.title: Disney’s ‘Zootopia 2’ Will Be a Test for Jared Bush
item.description: Jared Bush is trying to make the heart of the media empire beat more consistently. “Zootopia 2” will be a test.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jared Bush, as Disney Animation’s new chief creative officer, is charged with getting the studio back on track.

item.title: Donors to Trump’s Transition Revealed a Year Later
item.description: A 46-person list includes billionaires and people he went on to appoint to positions of power.
item.dc:creator: Ken Bensinger and David A. Fahrenthold
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: As president-elect, Donald J. Trump refused federal funds for his presidential transition, which would have required contributors to be disclosed within 30 days of taking office.

item.title: Britain Raises Taxes by More Than $30 Billion in Push for ‘Stable Economy’
item.description: In announcing the measures, Rachel Reeves, the top economic official in an increasingly unpopular government, cited the forecasts for slower growth and the need to hold down debt.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Pru/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Rachel Reeves, the chancellor of the Exchequer, announces the government’s annual budget in Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Announces Negotiated Prices for 15 Drugs Under Medicare
item.description: The Trump administration said that had the new prices been in effect last year, Medicare would have saved $12 billion, which would have reduced its spending on those drugs by 44 percent.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Helen Sessions/Alamy
item.media:description: The 15 drugs include widely used inhalers, such as Breo Ellipta, and treatments for cancer, diabetes and depression.

item.title: How Much Will Thanksgiving Dinner Cost? It Depends on Whom You Ask.
item.description: As Americans become increasingly concerned about affordability, there’s scrutiny on the annual meal.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper
item.media:credit: Connor Robinson
